review: The Apple TV works well enough, Airplay works alright though is overly complicated for my folks to use on a regular basis with their iPad 2 (it seems picky when using their apps, many of which are in Taiwanese). It's just a rather unspectacular device. Hulu and Netflix have terrible interfaces when compared to other versions of their software, there are no other non-iTunes stores that you can purchase movies from. And no Amazon unless you stream it through your iPad/iPhone.On the other hand, Airplay works well (though by no means flawlessly). iTunes has a very thorough store (though it too could use a facelift), and though added slowly, the Apple TV is getting some better channels finally. HBO Go here works on Comcast (*cough* Roku, wtf fellas *cough*).Recommendation: If you have a lot invested in iTunes or really want Screen Mirroring from your apple devices, get an Apple TV. Otherwise, there are better solutions out there.
author: Rich

review: We left our Roku behind and opted instead for the AppleTV.What we like:- Airplay, airplay, airplay- It downloads content pretty quickly, we have never had any slow network issues or Netflix buffering- The quality of the content playback is superb- Did I mention airplay?What we miss about our Roku:- I could install apps for the Roku, including custom apps that would stream content from a home serverIn summary, it's a great deal and has enabled us to rid our selves of the shackles of cable TV.

author: baotoan86

review: I cannot say enough good things about this unit. I purchased form Target for $99 plus tax. I cut the cable cord some years ago. I was between purchasing a Royku and this Apple TV. I wrote this review because some of the reviewers stated that smart tv owners would not want this. As a smart and basic HDTV owner, I disagree. Also, I cannot speak to the movie sources, etc. because that is not my interest. What I like most is the Airplay feature on the ATV. I have access to content I want on my iPad via the Internet. Being able to Airplay, and not just mirror is worth the purchase. I have used a a digital media adapter on the ipad before but there is no comparison in resolution or presentation for the adapter vs ATV and the adapter will cost about a third of the price for the ATV and still not airplay. So if you are thinking of going the adapter route - probably not. Some complained about the remote. I rather like the little remote, and like that it has some flex in it. I can see that it might get lost in sofa cushions, etc. but I am pleased with it. The ATV was extremely easy to set up. Another point I should make is that I installed mine on a secondary older HDTV that must be about 8 years old or more. As it relates to the discussion of older TVs, this works perfectly. It is an LG and has one HDMI port - ahead of its time when I purchased it. I was concerned about mounting the ATV on the wall mounted tv. I discovered that the ATV does not have to be visible for the remote to sensor to it, so I was able to hide the ATV in the tv casing. So if you want to watch movies, etc. there are apps for that. I like that there is free international news and other free apps. But I mainly use use Airplay to play iPad content - plenty video podcasts - such as time shifted cable news, and other feature programs, as well as free tv internet/cable/tv channels. Of course, photos, notes, and anything else can be air played as well. It did take a while to learn how to move from one tv input to the other without loosing tv functionality- but that is not a problem now. If you are not apple invested, and if you are mainly interested in movies- you may want to also look at a Royku, but this was a best solution for my purposes. And that should probably be the deciding factor, - what do you need a set to do for you that you cannot already do? Hope this helps and was not too rambling.And about You Tube, just Airplay it.
